>>9581124
Generally speaking there was a clear distinction between consoles and PC gaming, with fairly different titles on each system.

It wasn't profitable at the time for Devs to make games designed for (usually) one or two consoles with already massively different architecture work well on the huge variety of different hardware and drivers available for PCs in the early 90s and 00s.

PCs tended to specialise more in FPSs, Strategy games (both turn based and real time), point and click adventures (which were not great fun on consoles until the Wii), longer form RPGs and Simulators of various sorts. Consoles tended to focus much more on racers, sports games, beat em ups, platformers (both 3D and 2D) and shorter form RPGs. What you get now, which is things being played fairly consistently across multiple platforms simply wasn't commonplace. Ports from consoles generally weren't that great, ports from PC to console were often even worse.

There were of course some games that worked reasonably well on PC and Console, some that come to mind were:
- the GTA series
- The Tomb Raider series
- Resident Evil 2 onwards

PC gaming in the early 2000s was the best fucking thing ever. Imagine growing up on your brother's NES games, and then one day, you get a Win XP computer and you're playing Command & Conquer Renegade online with 64 other people, waging huge wars in giant battlefields. All of this on top of the culture of the era: it would be a friday night and you'd go downstairs, make pizza pockets, wait for Trigun or Cowboy Bebop to come on Adult Swim, boot up StarCraft on the family PC, try to sneak a beer or some liquor from your dad or smoke a cigarette without being found out... it was just a simple, wonderful time to be alive. If there's any period in my life that I could return to, it would be that magical era.

posts.com:
>>9581750
>I remember trying to save up for a Pentium with a 486 processor and a few hundred MEGABYTES of RAM. It cost $1500 - $2000 (USD)

That makes no sense. Pentium and 486 were different classes of Intel processors, the Pentium being what replaced the 486. That would be like saying you wanted to save up for an "I7-12700K with a I7-13700K Processor"

Also a few hundred megs of RAM? That is an ABSURD amount for the original Pentium. I highly doubt there were any consumer boards that could support even 128MB for the Pentium 1 back then, much less several hundred. 8 Megs of RAM was considered mid/high end for the Pentium 1 originally, 16MB later. It wasn't until the Pentium 3 that 128MB was becoming a more standard amount to have, and that was still not a budget amount. There is no way if the 486 was still relevant that you were looking at several hundred megs of RAM. The largest harddrives at the time were 1-2GB, putting several hundred megs of RAM in a system from back then is like the equivalent of having 512GB-1TB of RAM in your home PC today.

No, just the opinion of anyone who played it and had also played the SNES version, including me back then. I thought the game was glitched or corrupted or something when I heard the cacophony of "music".

Someone already posted a comparison video, how can you listen to that ear-rape and say it's a fine port? It's not just bad, it's not just a downgrade like the soundtrack of PC FF7 was, it's so horrific it might as well just be randomly generated notes. The sprites are all fucked too. Stretched and have a washed-out look to them, making them contrast far heavier with the background and giving them an appearance of not even belonging there when viewed on a CRT.

Is it as bad a Megman 1 for DOS? Obviously not, that wasn't even a port, that was an abomination to all that is gaming. But it's up there as one of the more infamously bad PC ports back then. A modern "bad" port isn't even close to what a bad port back then was like, now a port is considered bad if it has few configuration options, is locked at 30 FPS, and basically is exactly like the console version and didn't add configuration features for the PC version. But the truly bad PC ports were back from the 80s to mid 00s.

That's not to say there weren't good ports too, but when they were bad, they were REALLY bad. Destruction Derby for example was a pretty decent port to DOS:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-FDIp6fv2oo

Rollcage wasn't bad either:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_2Fv-3M-Ees

Come to think about it, both of those were racing games by Psygnosis. I recall liking many of Psygnosis's PC games back in the day.

>>9581124
Installers had access to the entire system and DLLs had no standard versioning system. Welcome to DLL Hell, where installing one program could literally break every other program with no way to diagnose it and often times the best solution just to reinstall the operating system, and then all your programs, and hope that you figure out an order that doesn't break anything.
Then you have 3d cards that only do one API properly (at best) so you don't even know what games are compatible, and that's on top of getting good drivers, which is a pain because your only hope is, at best, a 56k modem, and at worst a phone call asking your system builder to send you a driver disk, which they won't, because the tech support monkey is hell bent on being retarded.
But you put up with it, because at least it wasn't DOS.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: One thing I remember is that shovelware games had a big if ephemeral impact on the gaming scene because they were marketed to casual PC users on shelves at Office Depot and CompUSA, and also often came in cheap bundles that would come in magazines or be found in bargain bins at supermarkets. Ports and shitty remakes of arcade games were perhaps the most common type of shovelware during this era, but just about every kind of game imaginable was represented. As a kid in the 90s-00s, you often got a mix of these games and more legit games from your parents, and since the wait to get new games(not to mention the hardware to run them) could be a long one, sometimes you just had to hold your nose and dive into your shovelware backlog after you got burned out on the better games.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9584746
>So I'd like to port Project Babel's syncing and chaining to other monster mods, particularly when I make my own
Well, as the guy who made it, what you want to do is grab ProjectBabel\actors\babel_monster_base.txt and basically just copy it into your project. There are a few other dependencies in babel_static_functions.txt, but other than that you pretty much just inherit from SyncEnabledMonster or ChainEnabledMonster and use the appropriate hold state calls to make sure your monsters don't get their actions clobbered by signals at the wrong times. It's that simple.
As a bonus, those also include (but do not necessarily require you to use) the fear functionality.
>Also is there a reason cyberdemons and spider masterminds don't get in on the fun? Enhanced AI would be the perfect improvement to the lackluster masterminds
Honestly, for fear, it made some maps way too easy, or it had to have the thresholds set so high that it never happens. Like if you just BFG a bunch of hell knights and the sybie runs away, not fun.
For sync/chain, it just didn't seem to do much. I tested it out early on but the effects were negligible, so I removed them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9585458
>sybie
cybie*
Also, I forgot to mention: feel free to just chop out anything you don't want or rename stuff or whatever. The Hell Knight has some decent comments in it explaining what everything is and does, since it uses a little bit of everything. A lot of the stuff in Babel is fairly highly coupled, specifically for fear, but there's also things I never did like making weapons attract monster attacks and other fuckery with targeting. Once you get a grip on the basics of exactly what I did to get sync/chain to work you'll see it's fairly straightforward, honestly not complex at all. If you want to get more complex and make a mod that isn't trying to be vanilla+, but maybe a little more out there, there's a TON of things that you can do just by throwing triggers around and manipulating states. The Cacodemon, for example, uses the same kinds of signals for its dodges. You could go so far as to make paired enemies that always do complementary actions, or even potentially simple squad-based AI, that's just a lot harder than what I did and would probably blow up vanilla balance.

>>9585503
If you have a room or area you think looks too bland or empty, add some kind of an indentation to make it look a bit more varied. Here you can see there's the highest layer of green bricked floor, with a green cobblestone cross shaped identation which has some further cool shit added in the middle. Add shapes onto shapes with varied height to make things look more layered. The ceiling could be too just a black rectangle, but it looks better just by adding more smaller black rectangles into the black rectangles. It's good if the room has some kind of a landmark that makes it memorable, I'd say in this case it's the corpse pit in the middle. If you already have some detailing done, let's apply this example to the wooden pillars here, a simple idea to add more decoration would be trying to connect what's already there, in this case it's the metal bars coming out of the ceiling. It's a simple step but it adds an another layer to the ceiling while also making the pillars look more connected to it. Idk if I'm just overanalyzing shit here, but I tried to dissect what kind of thought processes would go into making a room like this.

posts.com:
>A brush consists of several faces, each of which is defined by a plane and additional texture information. The actual geometry of the brush is only defined by the planes, of which there must be at least four. Each plane defines a half space, that is, an infinite set of points that is bounded by a plane. The intersection of these half spaces forms a convex polyhedron. Note that the actual vertices of the brush are NOT stored in the map file. The vertices are determined by BSP (or a level editing program) by computing the intersections of the planes.
What the fuck was carmack thinking with this

But aren't they translated to actual vertices in the end? It shouldn't make any difference to the performance.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9586027
That's the normal way to do things. This is also how hardware rasterizes triangles: you have 3 line equations (in screen 2D space) and you test if the pixel is on the correct side of all 3 at the same time; if it is then it's inside the triangle (some details omitted).
The plane representation gives you a trivial answer to the question "is this point inside the volume?". The vertex representation gives you jack shit, and you need topology information on top because a set of vertices can define many shapes depending on how you group them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9586208
Dividing faces into polygons is one of the options to generate the picture. You can use some other rasterization method (scanline fill or ray casting, for example). Collision detection and visibility work with planes. Read something on how compiler tools process the map data from the editor, and why. If I recall correctly, Quake-related engines combine all static brushes into one complex enclosed space (the “inside” of the map where everything exists), then subdivide it with each face plane to produce many subvolumes touching each other. You can also check GoldSrc and Source documents from Valve, their principles are similar.

When you have planes, you know you have planes by definition. When you have polygons, you need additional calculations to get normals from positions of vertices (which accelerators can implement in hardware, but you can't), and, sometimes, to recover the fact that polygons belong to the same plane.

>>9585502
Here's what I got as a rough draft for the rules and general mapping tips.
A Serious Case of /vr/ Rules:
>Map must be made for Serious Sam The Second Encounter 1.07 version (this is the most up to date retail version you get from Steam/GOG)
>Usage of custom textures, sounds, and music is approved and encourged
>Usage of custom entities or other mods is NOT allowed. Outside of textures, sounds, and music your map should be 100% vanilla with 1.07
>Map must be beatable (duh)
>Map must have proper co-op support
>Do not make edits of existing maps
>Project host has the final say and can deny your entry if it is not up to /vr/ standards (please put some effort into your map)

Tips:
>Trigger a checkpoint whenever a new weapon is picked up to ensure everyone spawns with an "up-to-date" arsenal
>Make co-op portals for arenas that get closed off (and one-way doors for any closed off rooms/secrets so players don't get trapped)
>Aim to balance your map around Serious difficulty first, but don't be afraid to make support for other difficulties afterwards
>Also keep co-op in mind when balancing encounters
>"Hot Starts" are not that common in Serious Sam, try making a "lobby" room for players to jump around in without risk of triggering anything (useful for co-op)
>A good fight is more enjoyable than a good looking room, don't stress yourself out over brushwork
>Use the official maps as references (I won't berate you for coping models, texture work, etc. from official maps) (You can have multiple maps opened at once and switch between them in the editor)
>Get creative with secrets!

Any other important rules I might be missing for a mapping project?

posts.com:
>>9589385
I am not talking about compression. The difference is only relevant to specific groups of people dealing with specific kinds of information in a specific manner anyway. Not everyone get significant gains from that (in the same manner, a home user running optipng -o7 hoping to save a byte or two simply wastes electricity to heat the atmosphere). I am talking about user interface and attention to details. Anyone who is recommending 7zFM over WinRAR should be tested for dementia.

The zpaq site actually has the chart that EXPLAINS EVERYTHING:
http://mattmahoney.net/dc/zpaq.html

7-zip became famous at a very specific time (2000s), because it could give better compression on average compared to ZIP, a solution from the 80s, when amount of RAM in home computers had been 100 times (!) smaller, to say nothing of performance differences, and old RAR (mid-90s thing). Those who needed to fit as much as possible into the archive could choose to wait for it to do the work. If you used pirated games downsized to 1 CD or 1 DVD, you can probably remember that even decompression in installers using 7-zip was really slow on contemporary computers. However, as we can see, 7-zip is not only slow compared to older algorithms, it is also slow compared to other tools that give roughly the same archive size. Today, if your case is that specific one that benefits from properly chosen compression, you have the following choices:
— using a faster algorithm that gives the same size;
— using some modern really fast LZ* implementation that gives roughly the same results as expected from zlib, but can be often added for transparent on-the-fly compression and decompression;
— using a slower algorithm for maximum compression.

>How do I get the kill/item/secret count above the bar like in pic related?
Enable alternative HUD in the options and enable "Show secret count", "Show monster count", and "Show time widget" to get something similar to that HUD.

You can't enable auto pistol start and that feature will never be added to GZDoom.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9590695
for secrets and whatnot, you can try to enable the alternative HUD in GzDoom under Options > HUD > Alternative HUD > Enable, or use a custom HUD like HXRTC that can display level stats
and as for pistol start, there is no options to force it, so you need to do it manually, like using the idclev## cheat code or reloading the map through the console i.e. "map map01"

You can make a hotkey to do restart current level with a pistol by opening console and typing "bind ? map *"
Where "?" is whatever you want the button to be. Don't type quotation marks.

Serious Business Saturday starts in an hour (5pm US Central). If you want to download the map early we'll be playing today (called The Grand Portal) grab it here: https://files.catbox.moe/n0t4d4.gro
Some network changes that you should follow if you haven't already:
>Highly recommended to install the classics patch: https://dreamycecil.itch.io/sam-exe-patch if you haven't already. Adds a bunch of nice features like better resolution support and hud scaling. Make sure you grab the most recent TSE1.07 patch.
>Go into the Scripts\NetSettings folder inside your main TSE directory and open up the DSLCable.ini file. Change "cli_iMaxBPS" to 1000000. When connecting to the server MAKE SURE YOU SELECT DSL/CABLE CONNECTION.
>Upon loading into the main menu, type: "/cli_iMaxPredictionSteps=4" (no quotes) into the console. You only have to do this once. One note I should make is that this only improves performance for people with ping under 200-300 (I honestly doubt anyone has ping over this). The server is located in Texas so keep that in mind. If you encounter any problems with this setting then try increasing it.

Secondary reminder that I'm going to start the Serious Sam mapping project called "A Serious Case of /vr/" around next weekend. If you would like to start now feel free to do so. I have made a quick start guide you can follow that also has links to other mapping resources.
>https://rentry.org/vy4qr

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9591138
As in product? I don't know, you can get it for free, but for £6 you can get a version with some cool Buckethead .mp3s for the music. It's not standalone like Final Doom or Doom 64, but iD provides the free version of Sigil as one of the many optional level pack downloads for the new ports. That's however shared with decidedly less cannon fan works and even a TC.

Sigil would inherently have a greater 'claim' than anything else given the author, obviously he's effectively the 'director' of the original game. As much as Doom had any single firm creative direction, anyway, with guys like Adrian and Sandy inventing a lot on their own, often independently of Romero's input, and at times opposing his ideas. Even John Carmack and Bobby Prince would contribute or alter concepts, and a fair few of Tom's ideas and contributions remained in spite of his pitch for the game getting axed and his eventual firing.

Classic Doom and canonicity is a dicey subject though. There's Doom and Doom 2, but it gets pretty murky past that, these are not story heavy games, and products like Final Doom and Doom 64 present their own ideas about where it goes, Doom 2016 especially. In my opinion canon for Doom is unclear and greatly subjective (particularly with people involved coming up with ideas much later), but to me, Sigil seems like it'd fit ok between the first and second games.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9561476
>And less than 50 were built.

1993 was pre-internet so information is not available on the exact amount. However my research confirms around 25 to 30 Ridge Racer Full Scale Units were exported for Western/Foreign markets. They were spread across the USA, UK, Spain, France, Middle East, Australia, etc.

And around 20 Ridge Racer Full Scale were used in Asian markets. Namco themselves kept several units in reserve to use in their Namco branded theme parks and Namco arcades in Japan. Several independent arcade owners in Asia had a Ridge Racer Full Scale too. A few malls had them as well. In the 1990s, any business owner could buy it from Namco if they had the money.

Trust me. Namco would NOT invest money in a factory, put Ads in sales magazines (for arcade owners), make sales flyers, and only make a small handful of Ridge Racer Full Scale Units. You need bulk sales to make it worth the investment.

Different anon here. I actually had the chance to purchase a Ridge Racer Full Scale 20 years ago. The owner was closing his arcade and offered to sell it to me. But the guy wanted $15K. At most I could maybe $8K and the owner wouldn't come down in price.

It was 10 years old and the machine kinda worn, but it still worked. The interior needed to be redone. The leather interior and everything was worn down. Most home consoles looked far better than Ridge Racer Full Scale in terms of graphics. The arcade market had also crashed and many arcades were shutting down. Xbox live and online play had killed arcades.

I'm wondering if I made a mistake passing on this machine considering only a small amount were made and it seems no one else in the whole world saved their Ridge Racer Full Scale machines.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9563351
>are you sure? i saw one of these at pontins in prestatyn in late 90s/early 00s. If they only made 50 it's hard to imagine one would have ended up some run down holiday camp jn North Wales
No one knows the exact number for sure. Literally anyone with $250,000 to blow could have ordered a Ridge Racer Full Scale from Namco between 1993 and 1998. I'm not saying only 50 units were made. All I know is that I could only confirm around 50 with my research but more could have been made. It would not surprise me if more were manufactured.

Arcade collectors on forums like to say that only around 20 ridge racer full scale units were ever made, and pretend it was some sort of super rare machine. Which is complete bullshit. Namco would not invest millions into tooling an entire arcade factory and only make 20 units. They aren't Sega. Namco is actually well known for being financially responsible. It would not surprise me if 100 or 200 were made. I've talked to people that claim they saw Ridge Racer Full Scale in malls, movie theater lobbies, big arcades, theme parks, beach resorts, airports, etc.

>imagine one would have ended up some run down holiday camp jn North Wales
Your holiday camp probably bought them used at a big discount. During the early 2000s, many arcades were closing down because the arcade market crashed and never recovered. Businesses were selling their arcade machines on eBay and several websites for super cheap. That includes Ridge Racer Full Scale. I remember seeing them for sale. You could have gotten it for cheap if you had a few thousand dollars back then. I'm guessing a few places picked up a Full Scale for cheap and got a couple more years of use out of it until the machine broke down and was scrapped. Sucks that no one saved even one working unit.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9564774
Arcade business owners paid huge sums of money for arcade cabinets with the promise that they will earn their investment back in 6 months and start earning profit. Ridge Racer Full Scale was no different.

An arcade owner could pay $200,000 for Ridge Racer Full Scale. Yes that's huge for an arcade. But they could charge $5 dollars per play. Let's assume when it first came out that 500 people per day played Ridge Racer Full Scale. That $2,500 dollars a day. That's about $75,000 a month. That's $450,000 in 6 months. That's $900,000 in 1 year. It's already more than paid for itself.

I know you think these numbers are silly and absurd. But you don't understand. The 80s and 90s were a different time. Arcades were incredibly popular back then. A cultural phenomenon.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9564825
Ah...these ski machines. These things used to be everywhere. There aren't many "old school" Namco or Sega ski arcade machines like Super Alpine racer around anymore in arcades.

These machines saw a lot of abuse. People were very rough on the machines and the foot mechanisms were prone to breaking without periodic maintenance. People slamming their whole body weight left and right would eventually cause something to break. Many of these machines would break down as years passed.

The rear projection screens also were an issue as time passed. The bulbs inside needed to be replaced after a certain amount of hours of use. The bulbs cost money, and arcade owners don't want to invest money in keeping the screen running. Especially when LCD technology is now available.

They are also very bulky. If you do see a ski machine in arcades, it's probably a new one made Raw Thrills.

I'm not saying these old school Namco or a Sega Ski Machines are rare to find...Or that they worth a lot of money. They are out there and You could definitely find one for sale if you want on some websites. But shipping is expensive and it will probably need some sort of maintenance done.

Many arcade owners simply got rid of them after several years rather than continue maintaining them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9587862
>A single MAME cabinet with every arcade game ever made. Any other answer is hipster territory.
Mame doesn't even run a bunch of games properly. And there are many that don't run at full speed.

And I've actually owned a MAME cabinet. The biggest problem I've had with it is the fact it had "too many games". It was loaded with tens of thousands of games and you could spend hours scrolling through the menu. It takes way too long and bombards the user with too many options. Going through menus to reach the game you want isn't fun either.

MAME has its place for archival purposes or for people don't have a lot of space. But it is no substitute for the instant "pick up and play" appeal of arcades.

Famous arcade game designers from Sega and Namco have given interviews over the years. Here are some things they said.

- The arcade game must instantly draw a player in.

- It must offer the ability to instantly jump into the action.

- And most importantly... you have only "2 to 3 minutes" max to fully show off the essence of your game before the player losses interest.

These arcade designers got it down to a science. Wasting time on menus, and searching for a specific games is why MAME will never work in a public setting.

I used to have a MAME cabinet in my gameroom. I used it but visitors who came over didn't really enjoy it. I swapped it out for dedicated cabinets and people actually play it and enjoy it.

posts.com:
I never understood the point of these things. They cost something like $500-800, and play 1-3 or so games based on a series.

Yes, you can argue a real arcade cabinet of the game would have cost more, but those were dedicated hardware made to play that game, many times custom-made for the older arcade games. This isn't dedicated hardware, it's just software emulation and an LCD screen. It's like sticking a Raspberry Pi in an arcade cabinet.

The part I especially don't get is how for years we had arcade cabinets you could buy that came with a minimum of a few dozen if not hundreds of games, and many of those cost even less. It's like we went backwards, from Arcade cabinets costing $200-500 that come pre-loaded with dozens to hundreds of games... to arcade cabinets that cost $500-800 that play a single game. Again, if it was dedicated hardware at least it would make sense since it would be like having the actual original arcade cabinet, but it's not, it's paying hundreds more for the hardware in a PS1 Classic put in an arcade cabinet and with a single game on it. If these things were significantly cheaper I would understand at least, but not the outrageous prices they go for.

posts.com:
>>9591930
There was nothing stopping anyone with the programming ability and knowledge of doing that already with the existing source code for PS1 emulators. Most of the people with both just don't care enough to emulate a few specific arcade platforms outside of MAME. It can be done, it's just not likely to happen. Same with PCSX2 and System 147/246/256. It would be retardedly easy for the latter case, since there is very little difference between the PS2's main hardware and the main hardware used on those machines.
A far better solution would be for mature emulators for hardware that was also used in the arcades to extend their compatibility to target the arcade variants. Once an NES emulator supports every mapper properly, why not VS System games? Now Duckstation is pretty much complete, why not the GV and System 10/11/12? Dolphin abandoned work on Triforce games nearly 9 years ago, but the groundwork was laid. If it's based on console hardware, it shouldn't be that hard for the mature console emulators to emulate them as well. The rest can be left to MAME and compatibility layers like Teknoparrot or jconfig or whatever is hot these days.

>>9583547
NTA, but.
Point-and-click game with copious CGI, impressive production values, batshit insane plot, full voice acting, and it impressed Nintendo so much they hired a lot of the staff for their EAD team. It's Japan-only, for the moment being. Only times it got talked about before was when collector hoarders accidentally leaked a private mega folder with tons of games including this previously lost game.
Company did 3 games like these and folded shortly after. Supposedly uses a Macromedia type thing.

Some copyright troll trademarked a bunch of stuff including the logo for the game and took down most of the media about it online, and it looks more like erasing the game from existence than a prospective new release. Nearly nothing is left online.

The game is about a 5 year old American girl identifying as a bear (and portrayed as such) going to dangerous locations after hearing voices in her head. The game opens with her being refused a bus ride, that bus is bombed by terrorists and everyone is dead, the terrorists are gunned by an airplane and everyone is dead, and the girl inspects the bus and goes "It can't be helped". Then she has to avoid dying by starvation, getting hugged to death by a pedophile cop, getting killed in the crossfire of other terrorists in a public park where a schizophrenic woman thinks the heroine is daughter, and then an alien locale that defies description. I'm saddened the walkthrough was taken offline. I really want to see how this goes now that I learned more Japanese. The backstory intro roll itself (which is in English) alone is a riot.

>>9590557
The date scenes are almost too subtle for their own good. The game is amazing at narrative subterfuge, setting up the audience for a love triangle only to hint that there's something more going on. The language implies lovey dovey but the underlying meaning is way more straight forward. Aeris tells Cloud that he doesn't have to pretend to be someone else and that she'd rather meet the real person. Again, like a big sister telling her kid brother to stop pretending to be something he's not. With Tifa's date she tries to say something and backs off. She says "Aeris would be able to say it" or something along those lines. You think that it's an attempt at a love confession but it's really Tifa trying to confront Cloud about his bullshit and Tifa is acknowledging that Aeris is way more assertive than she is. Both girls are trying to use the date to have an intervention and the love triangle gimmick is the smoke and mirrors to disguise it to the player.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I think she's more important to Cloud based on his memories of his mother, where his flashbacks of her in Nibelheim are probably his most authentic. This makes the most sense because he never really knew or understood Zack's parents in Gongaga to really appropriate, and even when you do meet them, they act very different from Cloud's memories of his mother. Meanwhile, that Cloud in the flashbacks with his mother is probably the truest version of Cloud we see until the actual reveal come last disc.

She tells him to look for an older woman who can keep him in line, and Aeris does happen to be older, and while that isn't important, I do think the conversation hints more at why he's drawn to Aeris and the way she talks to him, even if that kiddish honesty of hers isn't exactly romantic and more arm's length, which is a luxury Tifa lacks and explains why she can never get to the point with him and can only say nothing at all for a long time.

I like the Cloud and Aeris pairing, but I don't think they were ever romantically drawn to one another. Cloud at most probably relates her to his mother, and that's why losing her feels hurts, but his inability to protect Tifa hits him so differently in comparison, he has to completely compartmentalize and repress the fact until he's no longer allowed to.

I feel like the distinction between adventure and action/adventure can be a bit tenuous. As long as there's still a solid focus on puzzles, I think it's still an adventure game. As far as I'm concerned the adventure genre became "survival horror" for a while. Resident Evil is an adventure game with combat, not a combat focused game that also has some adventuring (which would be RE4).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: They're still around, just in a different form. What we call "Visual Novels" in English descend from Japanese-style Adventure games like Portopia & Famicom Detective Club, which in turn decend both from games like Maniac Mansion and King's Quest as well as Text Adventure games like Zork & Colossal Cave Adventure. They've also partly been absorbed into RPG Maker games, which might as well just be Point-And-Click Adventure games without the pointing and clicking.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9589375

In the main, they were replaced by 3D action adventures, both on the PC, but also PS1 and N64 and people stopped making them because they weren't the money spinners they used to be. If you can make a game that you could port to the PS1 (which was pretty awkward to play point and clicks on, and I there were some) and sell loads of units, why would you keep making single system games?

I think also Grim Fandango probably marked the turning tide - though that was only a PC game; Lucasarts was (arguably) the top dog in terms of sales and storytelling when it came to these sorts of games, when they were no longer putting their resources into point and clicks, a lot of other studios maybe saw that as an omen.

There is an interesting take in this (quite long) article as well about the spiralling costs of trying to make point and click adventures with FMV, and trying to convince an increasingly more star studded cadre of actors to star in them, turning games into cinema - using Toonstruck (which I also love) as a case study: https://www.filfre.net/2022/06/toonstruck-or-a-case-study-in-the-death-of-adventure-games/

Ironically - I would say Grim Fandango (which is 3D characters on rendered backgrounds, and pre-rendered cutscenes) is a more cinematic game than most of what was put out with FMV. Some people still feel that it's the best Lucasarts adventure.

I'd at least partly blame 3D graphics.
Adventure games at their worst were about pixel hunting for shit you didn't know you needed to do stuff that made no sense.
With 3D graphics it becomes exceedingly difficult to hide stuff on the screen without making it impossible to find. Some games made it work but it was difficult.
At first companies attempted to use FMVs as an alternative but that dried out as most FMV games were shit. As adventure games died most companies just gave up on fancy graphics and just stuck to 2D which works out great in games like Larry 7 and even newer titles like Gibbous.

>>9589862
True, and there's some good value in many of those games, but it's not a formula which lends itself well to continuation. Either you keep doing the same things as before and the puzzles and riddles never challenge, or you go past what makes any fucking sense and it's not fun anymore. There's also just the ever extant approach of trial and erroring yourself through various item combinations at random until something happens, which can be done even in some of the good ones.

Something like Doom and Quake have extensive mileage because the challenge lies in the the fast action gameplay, and they have sets of monsters and weapons which can be used to construct a very wide variety of scenarios, which is why people continue making new levels for Doom as the game is soon becoming 30 years old.
There's no simple way to do that with the base formula of any of these point and click or text prompt games.

>>9566449
Nah, it was fine, unless you're opposed on-principle to the idea of Fox going around on-foot. Never understood the bitching about the controls, they were basically identical to GC Metroid Prime; if people could learn to play that, they could learn to play this. The Landmaster feels significantly more responsive than, say, the Scorpion from Halo. The Arwing is indeed slower and floatier than in 64, but that's kind of a necessity in the free roam levels where you're expected to navigate actual level geometry, as opposed to 64's all-range levels consisting of flying over empty plains.

The worst that can be said about Assault is that it's too short, completely linear, and the ground missions all have the same objective. Still easily better than Adventures and anything that came afterward.

There's semconflicting info in the manual and opening text. In her manual profile, it says that she's the "only survivor of her doomed home planet of Cerinia" and "roams the galaxy in search of answers." In the opening text, she "searches for the truth of her parents' death." Either way, she picks up a distress call in a small world in the Lylat system and investigates, the implication being that she has a feeling it's related to her troubles. You can infer that Cerinia was outside Lylat, she was orphaned recently, Andross had something to do with it and lured her, she dresses in a manner that's not unusual on her home planet, and that ship she used to board the Great Fox was probably how she initially arrived on the planet....
....and since absolutely none of that was followed through in the slightest, the Japanese version apparently cuts any and all mention of Cerinia or her parents, and doesn't even subtitle the line suggesting she might've recognized Andross, so she in the Japanese version has even less nuggets of back-story and is a totally random scantily clad blue adventurer.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I'm not big on "favorites" so I'll just pick a random character I like.

Nanami is an overbearing tomboy who despite being just a child herself acts as a mother hen to her adopted family. Fates see to it that her family gets split right down the middle and while voiceless protag and punished anti-villain type Joey (think Riku from KH or Sasuke from Naruto) become leaders of two factions at war with each other. But she's there trying to keep the remnants together and never show weakness and never let on how sad she is that her family is broken and basically being manipulated for other's purposes to solve problems way bigger than any of them.

But in particular she is party and driving factor to one of my favorite moments in all of gaming. At a point where she has pretty much given up with reuniting with Joey and where the cause seems to be going pretty good, she dares to dream a selfish dream and asks protag to run away for the good of the family. And obviously if you go through with it things don't end up so good and the player gets punished for trying to abandon the game, but it really helps makes Nanami feel human. She just wants things to turn out good for her family. Damn all the war and politics, damn whether or not the cause is good.

I still don't know what I feel about that ass-pull of a good ending where it revealed that she faked her death so that protag could face Joey with a sense of nothing to lose, though. I mean sure it was Shu's idea and that checks out, but it was a dick move if you can even consider it canon.

>But analog triggers are a good thing in my POV. They are discrete shoulder buttons that act just like that until the aspirant player try a racing game and learns their magical thing spontaneously
Depends on the triggers. The GC triggers have an enormous amount of travel and relatively high resistance so they work poorly as digital triggers. The Wii Classic Controller and PS2 shoulder buttons are analog but the triggers are very shallow so it's hard to be precise with analog inputs.
I think the Xbox controllers and the DS4 ultimately struck the best balance. And what the Dualsense is doing with adaptive resistance is very interesting too.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9574569
Shitty arguments.
Except maybe for the lack of select.
But the concept of the game cube controller is basically to have primary and secondary controls.
You will instantly have access to the left stick, the A button and L and R, that's the main buttons.
Everything else is secondary, and you should be able to play without using them, or rarely.

Now, games developed for the console were not simple arcade games like Nintendo wanted.
So you needed to access more buttons, sometime at the same time. And, using a combination of B, X and Y was painful (like, literally sometimes).
No second Z button wasn't that problematic, but still, putting a "W" button on top of L couldn't hurt. Same as select, they probably wanted a simple af controller.
The C stick wasn't bad, as it was premilarly used for camera in basic games.. But when using in FPS, it needed a few time to adapt.

So, in a nutshell, yes, the gamecube controller design wasn't good, but not for the reasons you stated.
The controller was designed with a way of thinking in mind, as the whole console should have developed.
But the game developers didn't follow the Nintendo way of thinking (and it was a good thing, the developers were adapting to the marked and need of the players, they were merely doing what they could with what they have).
So, as usual, Nintendo had precise ideas about what the video game industry should be, and they failed to sense the market.
But, if you only take in account their vision, the controller was really good. Too bad their vision didn't match the reality.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Time Splitters (only on Game Cube)
>Time Splitters 2
>Quake 3 : Arena
>Half-Life : Decay (only on Playstation 2)
>Serious Sam : The First Encounter
>Serious Sam : The Second Encounter
>Metroid Prime (only on Gamecube )
>Medal Of Honor : Frontline
>Unreal Championship
>007 : Nightfire
These were the good games which looked modern and were on PS2, XBox, and Gamecube between 2000 to 2002. Certainly worthy competitors in the market (Metroid Prime maybe not aiming for the exact same market segments), but with the edge of splitscreen and online multiplayer, together with overall being a good game with good presentation, marketed strongly, I don't think there's any wonder why it did quite well for itself.

However, people forget that if you wanted a first person shooter on XBox, that Halo was the ONLY one there until 2002, where you would see a couple of middling games until roughly about a year after Halo's launch, where you'd finally see some good games on the console like Unreal Championship, Serious Sam, Timesplitters 2, etc. Thus, Halo had basically an unchallenged share of the market for a time, where its reputation did it well against middling or nonexistent competition on its home turf, letting it establish itself pretty well, with the PC port not coming until 2003, and which wasn't quite great, so if you were interested in Halo you probably wanted to get it on XBox. This would help set the stage for Halo 2 in 2004, which was a real barnburner, selling over two million units on its release day, and which had a popular and enduring multiplayer scene.

tl;dr it was a good game which in some aspects had limited competition, with a series which kept growing in popularity as it went.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
You know what Halo was? The quintessential 7/10 that was released at the perfect time and on the perfect console. The only reason anybody continues to talk about this series like the second coming of the jeebus is because, for a brief window of time, it was the only semi decent game on a largely terrible platform -- and it was marketed by one of the biggest, most influential companies on earth. The game itself is painfully derivative; its sole contribution to the genre was making analog control scheme standard for console shooters. In every other way, Halo ranges from mediocre to outright bad. Let's talk about some of Halo's "innovations"...
>game begins with superhuman cyborg badass running away from every enemy he sees while human soldiers defend him, until he can find a general that gives him a weapon (and says he doesn't keep it loaded, even though he does. because uhhh... no reason at all.)
>first real level drops you into a wide open environment with absolutely 100% fuck all nothing to find, where you'll skirmish with a handful of small enemy groups and then drive a buggy and then it's over
>later levels are either most of the first few levels played in reverse, or the library, where you walk through endless blue corridors shooting the shittiest enemy ever designed for a video game for 2 hours
>every weapon is complete dogshit and outclassed in almost every way by the very first weapon you find. in fact, the only reason to ever use any other weapon is when you have no pistol ammo. at best, you might use the rocket launcher or sniper a few times in very circumstantial instances.
>no online multiplayer except on PC (which was botched), they seriously expected people to play 3-4 person splitscreen on giant empty as fuck maps unless they could convince a dozen fat retards to come to their house and play LAN (which 99% of players never did despite what anyone tells you)
This game, by the way, sold almost 1/2 as many units as Goldeneye.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9579129
Grenade buttons weren't invented by Halo, but that doesn't mean that Halo didn't have a part in popularizing them. There's many cases where an aspect may get credited to something even if it wasn't actually the first game to ever do it, often it's because the game in question did it both in a good way, and the game sold well, making a good and visible example.
You can look at FPS as a whole for this, Wolfenstein 3D gets touted as the original first person shooter, but it isn't true, aside from iD themselves having made the Catacomb 3D and Hovertank 3D games back when they were still the Gamer's Edge division at Softdisk magazine, there's simple first person shooting games on arcades and even computers and consoles which predate that.

What Wolfenstein 3D does though is put the player in a 3D space with textured walls, where they can move freely, and there's a focus on FAST gameplay, no fiddling with any stats or inventory, it's just shooting the gnutzis, avoiding getting shot as much as you can, while managing your resources and finding the exit to the next level (which may involve up to two different keys), finding treasures and secrets confers benefits of extra lives and putting yourself on your own personal scoreboard.
The gameplay is perhaps slightly too simple (hence being quickly overshadowed by Doom, which hits a fantastic balance), but more importantly it was a fast and widely available first person action game unlike any other.
Thus, it gets credit for assembling this into the very base formula that came to change the world.

Of course, nothing Halo does actually REVOLUTIONIZES anything, huge hits had done it all before, and it didn't reinvent grenade buttons, games like Team Fortress Classic already implemented those well, but it was one of those games which made the concept really take off because it was a fairly big commercial and critical hit which implemented the mechanic well and made it a prominent feature of its popular multiplayer.

This is because the levels were heavily scripted, so for example someone might say "wow that elite took cover behind this corner there when it's shields were down, that was clever" - players don't know that Bungie just added these places into the terrain. >the short time to kill, recharging shields/health
Honestly, I was never a huge fan of this concept but I think Halo 1 nailed it the best with the longer recharge time and and needing to venture to health packs. When they shortened the timer and fast regenerating health, for Halo 2 and beyond, it made the dynamic even worse (encourages people to just hide out of the action).

I don't care much for regenerating health, I find it's usually a crutch for not wanting to do better level design, but grenades being a quick button instead of its own defined weapon to manually switch to is just fucking practical and makes grenades more viable and fun. With a button I can just make a grenade throw and it automatically returns me to my weapon afterwards, that's smooth and I don't need to come to a halt, you can make the gameplay faster for it, and in return increase the challenge for the player to match their abilities.

In Half-Life, I find myself not using hand grenades all that often because that requires that I stop shooting what I'm using now and switching to another weapon, manually throwing it, and then switching back. Because of that, in the heat of combat I basically never ever use them because I don't want to let up the pressure, whereas I gladly use the grenade launcher altfire because it's very conveniently attached to my machinegun (and it also detonates on impact).
The role I end up using them for (aside from maybe demolition or setting off tripmines from around a corner), is if I have the drop on an enemy, in which case one or two grenades are my opening before lay down fire. This is useful, but more occasionally, and the grunts tend to avoid it, which in itself isn't bad, it's nice that different enemies require differing tactics and approaches, that's good, but it makes the already limited grenades still more limited.

If I instead chuck one with a dedicated press, I could maybe use it when in actual combat with the grunts, if nothing else to flush them out or suppress them.

Bungie's Halo franchise had a significant impact on the video game industry for several reasons:

Revolutionary gameplay: Halo's gameplay was a revolutionary combination of fast-paced first-person shooter action and vehicular combat, with a strong emphasis on strategic thinking and teamwork. This new type of gameplay was a major departure from traditional shooters, and it quickly became popular among players and critics alike.

Story and world-building: Halo's story and world-building were also highly praised, with the game's rich lore and deep universe drawing players in and keeping them engaged. The game's story was complex and well-written, with a strong emphasis on the themes of humanity, sacrifice, and the struggle against an alien threat.

Multiplayer: Halo's multiplayer was also a major contributing factor to its success. The game's smooth, responsive multiplayer gameplay and robust matchmaking system made it easy for players to connect with others and play together online. The game's multiplayer mode was widely regarded as one of the best of its generation, and it helped to popularize online multiplayer gaming.

Xbox: Halo was a launch title for the Xbox and it was one of the main reasons why the console was successful. Halo helped to establish the Xbox as a major player in the console market, and it helped to expand the audience for console gaming.

Innovation: Halo was innovative in many aspects, such as the use of the shield system to regenerate health, the use of vehicles, and the AI of the enemies. These features were not present in most of the first-person shooters at the time and they helped to set Halo apart from its competitors.

Overall, Halo's combination of revolutionary gameplay, engaging story, and exciting multiplayer helped to establish it as a landmark title in the video game industry and solidified its place as one of the most iconic franchises in gaming history.

Bungie's Halo: Combat Evolved had a huge impact on the industry for several reasons:

- Gameplay: Halo's gameplay was praised for its smooth and responsive controls, as well as its diverse and challenging AI. This made it stand out among other first-person shooters of its time and set the standard for future console shooters.

- Storyline: Halo's storyline was praised for its depth, complexity and cinematic qualities. It was one of the first console games to have a fully-realized, cinematic story experience.

- Multi-player: Halo's multi-player component was also a major contributing factor to its success. The game's multi-player mode, which allowed players to compete against each other over a network, was a major breakthrough for console gaming, as it helped to establish the console as a viable platform for online gaming.

- Technical achievement: Halo was also a technical achievement for its time, featuring impressive graphics and a large, open-ended level design, which helped to create a sense of immersion and freedom for the player.

- The Halo franchise has also been a major contributor to the Xbox brand, Halo being one of the Xbox's most successful franchises and helping to establish the Xbox as a major player in the console market.

All in all, the combination of these factors made Halo a groundbreaking game that set new standards for the industry and helped to establish the Xbox as a major player in the console market.

>>9589797
This post is absolute truth. Hearing those rapid MP40 THUMPS the first time was really something.
I remember feeling really guilty as a kid the first time I came upon that guy walking around on the first level and shot him to death. I wasn't that accurate of course, so I had to watch him fall to the ground wounded and try to catch his breath while I figured out how to aim the gun downwards. Poor guy just wanted to go for a walk and have a cigarette, I have no idea what his political beliefs were, and if I'd taken a different path through the forest he would have lived. Similar feeling to the first time I caught a fish, bashed its brains in, and then saw it wiggling around a few minutes later because I (possibly) didn't land the blow correctly. Knowing it was suffering purely because of my own incompetence. The realism in the game was way ahead of anything else. They weren't robots, they were people wheezing on their backs, staring at their wounded arms, and freezing in shock after their helmet flies off and they realize that they could have been (and are about to be) dead.

>>9590805
> Three soldiers standing in a group

MOH had some pretty neat AI for its time. A soldier might just run away from a grenade, he might kick it away, or he might try to pick it up and throw it back at you.

If they get shot in the arm they'll grab it in pain, and then shoot one handed at you. If they get shot in the leg they'll collapse and try to crawl away. They'll hide around corners and desperately blindfire at you.

All of this is of course tempered by the fact that they will charge you one by one while you're sitting in an machine gun nest letting you mow them down, but considering the game released in 1999 it's still pretty impressive.

It was cool to finally see an RE game with fully rendered 3D environments. Claire is one of the best protagonists and Chris is there also, I guess, also the presentation and graphics were top notch at the time. That said, the level design was too spread out and it's a pain for new players, the plot was kind of meaningless in the grand scheme of things and that Leo pastiche guy was largely disposable as a character. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
CODE: Veronica was released in an age where a large number of players went in blind without being spoiled by social media, youtube, online FAQs etc. Spoilers were taken seriously on forums at the time. A lot of players tried to play the game like RE2/3 where ammo falls from the sky. They binned the knife, didn't search too hard for ammo, got fucked over with the fire extinguisher, the tyrant boss fight, the post Nosferatu switch, soft locking themselves at Alexia I, the dumb glass cannon, wonky Steve "fight". CV was a very polarizing title from the outset.

Most media outlets were very positive on the DC version as it was a major step forward with the graphic fidelity and away from pre-rendered backgrounds. By the time CVX was out (Summer 2001), the graphics were stale and the PS2 ran like ass so Capcom added some Matrix Cutscenes for Wesker which knee caps Alexia power-lever and opens the door for cornball RE5.

RE3 got a B reception upon release but received a major resurgence in the age of nostalgia and speed running as it is the best playing single player distillation of the RE formula. I expect CV to get a resurgence in the coming years as the pendulum of contrarianism swings against RE3 and to the appreciation of CV's uniqueness as an RE title.

>>9579036
Its overly linear, spread out and back track heavy. The game's weapons lack punch, foley is weak, enemy design is inconsistent, there is way less model damage on enemies and player characters when they are hurt. It lacks the QOL upgrades RE3 brought to the controls. These factors make it a chore to replay.

>>9579791
The Last Escape is a nothing burger with a nothing character (Jill), the only thing that matters is one epilogue for a character that isn't even in the game (Leon). RECV brings back Wesker and sets the arc for RE4/5.

I'll partially forgive that one because players should have been wondering why it didn't disappear after using it but you don't find out until hours later why you need it.
>oh you didn't know that you were switching to Chris after the nosferatu fight and you had all your weapons on Claire? lol reload your last save or severely gimp your run as Chris
>time to switch back to Claire, I hope you have plenty of healing items for her to use in a few minutes
>no healing items? it's okay bro just do this ridiculously hard and not obvious at all maneuver to get Steve stuck in a corner for a few seconds and you should be able to trigger the next cut scene with just a few pixels between you and Steve's ax
I know there's a few more but I can't remember them right now. I do enjoy how CV is generally more difficult than the other fixed camera RE games but CV definitely had some bullshit moments that just screwed over players without prior knowledge of the game and it rightfully gets criticized for that. The voice acting went firmly back towards RE1 on the slider scale of voice acting.

I ended up liking the game anyway, but goddamn was it hard, plus way longer than the usual old-styled RE game. The story was what kept me interested the most. The Ashford twins made for some really interesting villains and the fact they came from aristrocracy allowed for pretty good operaesque aesthetics sometimes. Since we're talking about divisive/ hated RE entries, I just got RE0 discounted on ps4 and it's the one game from the main series I haven't played to completion yet, disregarding the remakes.
I remember playing it a little on my brother's gamecube a while back and making it out of the train until I got to some monkey enemies that tore my shit apart.
Didn't seem half bad back then, especially the train had good atmosphere, but I do know the traditional inventory system was ditched for a shared one with your partner and being able to leave things on the ground to pick up later. Theoritically I suppose this whole system makes for really strategic use of your ammo and inventory management but I'm guessing it also adds a whole lot of tedium and I hear it's among the hardest RE titles for it.

Will see.

>>9580341
>Most media outlets were very positive on the DC version as it was a major step forward with the graphic fidelity and away from pre-rendered backgrounds. By the time CVX was out (Summer 2001), the graphics were stale and the PS2 ran like ass so Capcom added some Matrix Cutscenes for Wesker which knee caps Alexia power-lever and opens the door for cornball RE5.

Resident Evil: Code Veronica started out as a port of Resident Evil 2 for the Sega Saturn. But Nextech who was in charge of porting the Saturn game, had issues with RE2 to the Saturn, which caused its' cancellation.I think Sega may have suggested making the game for the Dreamcast, instead. Nexttech made the Code Veronica game engine, which was essentially the RE2 game engine running with 3D environments. I almost thing Code Veronica was going to be a 3D remake of RE2, before Capcom decided to make it a new game. Code veronica was originally planned to have both Leon and Claire, with Leon being replaced by Steve Burnside. When Code Veronica was first shown off to the public, the game was treated like a technical showcase for the Dreamcast, and it was the first 'next generation' Resident Evil game. The game did get released months before the PS2. The real-time cinematics and cinematic game models were really impressive for their time. The game was one of the best looking games on the DC outside of Shenmue I and II. But when it was ported to the PS2 and Gamecube (clearly much more powerful hardware) , the game lost some of its luster, when put up against other games on those consoles. Resident Evil 2 and 3 did get Dreamcast ports, but these ports are basically the PC games running on WindowsCE.

Not that anon, but I would put it like this:

>Two main characters that are highly differentiated from each other with each having a lot of shit to collect ranging from weapons, subs, magic,head/body/leg gear and accessories with all sorts of different effects lending to different kinds of playstyles
>Three bonus character modes that are more limited in player character scope but nonetheless offer a changed experience that you might even enjoy more than the main chars including Richter and Maria trading their SoTN powerlevels for speed, kinda
>Hard mode with level caps that can turn the game into an intense 2-hits-tops affair
>A lot of different areas even if it is handled differently than usual with a lot of bosses including arguably some of the sickest shit you'll see in the metroidvanias if not Castlevania period
>Also has some fun and occasionally goofy stuff to fuck about with
>Mileage may vary on the story and I personally dislike it for a bunch of stuff but also appreciate it for others, arguably a better attempt than other vanias

Maybe it's just nostalgia since PoR was my first metroidvania, but even after playing all the other ones and appreciating them more and more over the years, PoR is one my favorites out of that line of games and even one my favorites overall.
>I tried Dawn, and it seemed like the exact same shit as Aria meaning the exact same shit as sotn, sprites and all
Uuh, this might be a bit of a damper, but PoR does indeed reuse SoTN's template and also tends to reuse quite a bit of stuff from prior games, including enemy sprites from Dawn, even. That said, as you might guess from the above points and >>9582480, I would say that PoR handles that stuff better when it comes to gameplay and game design. A refinement rather than something totally new, and unless you're that tired out on it all after playing those three, I'd like to think you could still in fact enjoy it more than those despite that.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
All the Igavania games are good in their own ways.

SOTN is easy but it's still the most audiovisually lavish and atmospheric, and has a metric fuckton of fun shit to play with.

COTM feels like Richter mode on steroids. It's got some quirks to it but it's got some of the most engaging challenges of the series with some enemies that start to feel more like shmup bosses.

HOD is probably the weakest by far. I like its art-direction in parts and some of the spells are cool and punchy, but easier than sotn and also has a lot of jank and annoying shit.

Aria has a cool plot twist and is a return to form after HOD, but I feel it's not standout in any one area besides that.

Dawn I think has better music, bosses, and overall presentation of Aria even if it's somewhat of a retread of that game.

Portrait is interesting. More experimental than Dawn with more varied art design thanks to the portraits. I don't remember if I'd call it harder than Dawn, maybe a bit more uneven? But its highs are high.

Ecclesia had an ex contra guy on staff and I think it shows. Easily the most combat focused game. I think the combat is fun enough even if the level design isn't up to snuff, and the later parts of the game are extremely strong. Like Portrait it has some low lows and some very high highs.

That's my opinion on all of them.

>>9587508
Actually, in fact, thinking on it more, while I think I get what you mean about SoTN's bosses getting to attack more and not just letting you wallop them, I don't fully agree with that, nor do I agree that this makes them harder by default. A good handful of them do indeed practically stand there and take it like Medusa and the mummy, and others like Malphas(?) take a hit and get stunlocked to death. Not all of them fall into these categories, you got think the hippogryph (sp) and Orlox, Scylla, Richter's a motherfucker if you don't bamboozle his AI with distanced jump attacks, but some of those have a counterpart in HoD, sometimes with their own advantages, and a good deal of HoD's bosses have a gimmick that prevents you from indeed just standing there and flogging them to death.

Not only that, but even the ones that let you get hits on them are, in fact, still moving around, such that staying put will actually get you whapped around, and they all have the resilience to outlast you. Yeah, boss rush has a secret Simon mode, and you can totally get through it unscathed, even, but that requires actually getting good and paying attention to their nuances, and you'll just flat out not make it as Simon or really even Juste or Maxim if you don't.

That isn't all to say that hurr durr HoD is actually le hard, and really, HoD's bosses aren't exactly the same or anything as SoTN's, so I think one can absolutely have preferences to which group you'd like to fight, but I honestly think saying that HoD's are just plain damn easier than SoTN's is wrong.

posts.com:
It’s a great series. The original is just an old school arcade rail shooter done excellently. The graphics look good for the release too. Remember it released closer to Starfox 1 than Starfox 64.

Zwei improved on the original in almost every way. Saving, multiple routes, deeper scoring, better graphics, Pandra’s box and higher difficulty all made this a huge step up. Music is the only thing that might be better in the original.

My biggest and really only problem with the first two games is their short length. But if thats the worst thing about a game its probably pretty good. Many of the best saturn games were short.

Saga is a great, unconventional RPG with an excellent unique battle system and interesting story. Flying around exploring and trying to solve puzzles and win battles is so much fun.

Orta may be mechanically and gameplay wise the best in the series. Its finally long enough and had enough depth. The story is batshit insane but I just ignore it. Great bosses and more strategy in the gameplay. Plenty of extra features.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9583137
Saga is a near prefect game, and easily in my top 10. My only gripes are that it's too short (~15 hours even if you 100% it), and not all that well balanced. I guess on my first playthrough it was reasonably challenging, but only because I didn't know the "trick" for each enemy. Once you do, the game is laughably easy. There's not one, but TWO sub-bosses near the end of the game that can be defeated without them even having a chance to attack you.

The first game is stylistically cool, but very unremarkable in terms of gameplay. Zwei was a massive improvement and I enjoyed it a lot. It even has replay value due to the multiple routes in its levels, whereas Panzer Dragoon did not.

Super Mario is an incredibly easy game to pick up and play for just about anyone, but beating it warpless is another story. It's not among the hardest NES games, but it's probably the hardest classic Mario game aside from the Lost Levels, and I'd rank it as similar in difficulty to Castlevania or Metroid, two games some people consider quite challenging.
I just did it for the first time a few months back and it took me most of an evening to do so, plus I got lucky once or twice during the run.
Keep trying, you can do it! Remember that indecision is death and sometimes just cutting loose and running full speed is a good idea. So much of the game seems designed to punish you for overthinking a situation rather than just sprinting and jumping through with confidence. It is an athletic game, after all, according to its creators.

This is the actual one stop solution for emulation. Not FPGA memeshit, not mini console scalped bullshit, not original hardware which is difficult to store and can be expensive.

This has the ultimate form factor, decent performance, HDMI output and the bluetooth and wifi.

You get one of these, put a frontend onto it like LaunchBox or Retrobat (Retrobat is much more plug and play), put a ROMset on it and throw a CRT filter and BOOM you’ve instanty mogged every other retro setup.

This is the best solution also because these only cost $100 if you buy them second hand. The inputlag is actually very not noticable for me at all.

You can even get an airmouse/keyboard and your entire setup is wireless with small controllers that works on a modern TV. AND you can put indie games on the frontend too so you can load in and out of an entire game collectionn not to mention other home entertainment like movies, tv and anime.

>>9576783
I have a small form factor Optiplex (smaller than a tower, but not as tiny as this ThinkCentre), and it works quite well for this purpose. However, >>9576825 >>9576845 and >>9576850 have a point in that the integrated GPU can be quite limiting. In my case it's just barely good enough to output in 4K, but it's too weak for using anything but lightweight shaders at that resolution, and it struggles to render at anything higher than 2x resolution on PS2 and GC/Wii games, and sometimes not even that. For this reason I ended up getting a GPU, though I was limited in my choices due to the small form factor, but I can say even a low-end GPU is a vast improvement.

tl;dr it can definitely work, but you have to temper your expectations a bit when it comes to graphical output. Still better than a memeberri pi or chinkbox though.

>>9577038
Power conservation matters for 24/7 servers. You will see a hit on the power bill running an old server or desktop like that. An RPi not so much.

A device that is on an hour or so a day will cause a marginal effect.

I used to run xeon servers at home. I scaled down to a nuc and virtualization. Then I scaled down again to a few RPis. I wouldn't suggest RPis for anything needing equivalent or greater than a modern laptop compute, because it isn't going to be enough. I would only use RPi for a low power always on solution.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9587551
Regarding the region mod for the Megadrive: It doesn't really matter if you are using RGB. You'll only have problems when using composite video because the color subcarrier frequency is different for PAL and NTSC. Although you could fix this if you combine the region mod with a DFO that actually changes the subcarrier frequency depending on the region.

If you don't want to be able to switch back to PAL, you can hard mod the Megadrive as well and just replace the crystal to get the correct NTSC subcarrier frequency.

Can't speak for the Saturn, but most likely you won't have any issues if you are using RGB.

>>9587559
This is probably the best advise if you just plan on playing a bunch of NTSC games or want to get a flash cart. The cost and effort of region modding a Megadrive isn't worth the hassle. Also, I've had compatibility issues with my modded Megadrive and the Everdrive.

Luckily the Megadrive isn't "that" expensive, but the Saturn will set you back a couple hundred €.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9587551
A pal MD cannot generate a proper NTSC signal due to having a slightly different master clock crystal. However NTSC sucks ass anyway, so you need to mod the console to output PAL60. To do the PAL60 mod you need a 4.43Mhz crystal oscillator to drive the color encoder chip, and also hardware the pal/ntsc pin of that chip to always be PAL.

Interesting, I was on Guru's blog recently and read something related to this. http://members.iinet.net.au/~lantra9jp1_nbn/gurudumps/

>There's a 555 timer, some caps, resistors, diodes and a pot. It's a spark killer board. There are 5 wires connected to it.... black; ground, red; 5V, blue, white and green. The blue and white wires are connected to the main board reset section and the green wire is just floating in the air. The green wire is an antenna that detects the spark. The blue and white wires send a signal to the reset section on the main board and reset the game if a spark is detected. There's a pot that most likely adjusts the sensitivity of the spark detector. So even back in 1980 game manufacturers were well aware of rambunctious kids and piezo sparkers hehe!

>>9583294
>There isn't a single great Sega console.
Master System and Game Gear were both excellent 8bit consoles filled with classics, of course they both couldn't compare to their main competitors, NES and Game Boy respectively, but that doesn't take away from the quality of their hardware and their success in some regions of the world outside of North America and Japan, they're still quite fun to play even nowadays. Genesis/Mega Drive is still a fantastic 16bit machine with most of SEGA's classic franchises, and near perfect arcade adaptations too, it was SEGA's most succesful console for a reason, it has hardware that was ahead of its time, and a library filled with quality titles in most genres, regardless if you prefer the SNES over it or not, just the fact that it managed to rival what could be the most perfect console of all time, the SNES, shows how good it was. If you want to talk about its add-ons, the 32x really was quite bad, but the CD had some decent titles for its time. At last we have the Saturn and Dreamcast, which weren't as succesful, but the Saturn's library isn't bad, especially in Japan, and the Dreamcast had probably the best launch lineup ever.

>Sonic's gameplay never worked.
>Every blind playthrough on the internet proves
I see this take getting posted a lot nowadays, the whole "Sonic was never good" nonsense, and that's exactly what this sort of comment is, nonsense. Sonic is probably the only franchise where people seem to feel proud of themselves for being really bad at it, like it turns them into a video game connoisseur to suggest that one of the most beloved and succesful franchises of all time is somehow fundamentally flawed. You can't expect to pick up the controller and be good at it from the get go, no video game is expected to let you just do well and win right away.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9584638
>Yes, thanks to the Genesis still selling quite well in the west even by then.
The Genesis wasn't selling well. Sales of the console had dried up by 1996 and there's evidence the software sales were tanking even sooner than that. People were buying the systems in 1994 and 1995 as cheap budget systems, but not the games at full price. A lot of games were being given away for free or dumped in bargain bins. And even though the systems were selling better than the software, it was still nothing compared to what the PS1 and even the Saturn were selling at the time.

That massive loss you see in FY98 is because Sega of Japan took over, realized there was a shitton of unsold Genesis hardware and software sitting in warehouses and they wrote them off to get rid of them. They then re-evaluated Sega of America's assets and net worth and it made a huge dent in their financials.

How things worked back then was that Sega of America bought hardware (consoles, accessories, etc.) and software (mostly cartridges as CDs were being printed everywhere) from Sega of Japan. So every time Sega of America ordered more stock, that counted as a sale in Sega of Japan's export revenue. But that stuff wasn't selling and was sitting in warehouses. So the parent company's finances were looking ok because of those "sales", but the subsidiary was doing much worse, but it wasn't being reflected accurately. So when Japan took over in 1996-1997, they realized this massive mess was going on, wrote off all the inventory and got rid of it. But that meant now those "sales" from previous years were actually losses and it made a huge impact.

Bullshit. There were third party games still releasing for it as late as 1998. The bulk of third parties that mattered had already moved on to the PS1, N64, and even the Saturn.
>the 32X fiasco that SoJ forced on SoA.
This is an out of context statement that keeps getting regurgitated without context. 32X wasn't FORCED on Sega of America. The fabled phone call in 1994 that peopel quote was in response to Sega of America continuing to drag their feet and not get behind the Saturn. They didn't want to release it and instead wanted to stick to the Genesis. Which again, the Genesis was showing it's age and software sales were beginning to slump. So this phone call was Japan going "Ok if you don't want the Saturn what the hell do you want and what the hell are we going to release here to counter these new upcoming systems?"

So eventually Sega of Japan gave in and agreed that they wouldn't release Saturn in the US yet and would instead focus on the Genesis and offered an enhanced Genesis with more colors to try and extend it's life. Sega of America countered with the 32X. So no, the 32X wasn't forced on Sega of America. It was Sega of Japan giving Sega of America exactly what they wanted.
>The developer of Sonic X-Treme outright said that SoJ refused to give SoA the game engine of Nights into Dreams.
Which has been debunked by Yuji Naka. NiGHTS was a game hardcoded in Assembly. People who have dug into the game to try and datamine and reverse engineer it have confirmed it's very obvious that it's handwritten assembly and not compiled C code. As a result, that code was useless for anyone trying to make their own game because it wasn't an engine and wasn't easy to use in any way like that.

Naka stated he doesn't even remember anyone asking for it.

They literally have a fast-travel system for it. If your hub requires a fast-travel warp, it's too fucking big.

In Mario 64, going from the entrance of the castle to Tick Tock Clock, one of the last levels, takes about 25 seconds. And that's a casual walk, without doing any advanced movement tricks.
